Articles.Content: Hi. I'm now addicted to this sim!!! Anyway, I think I have broken free of Earth's gravity. I am at roughly 88,000 km at a constant speed of 35573 m/s. I have not slowed down at all. My speed has been constant for over 30 minutes!!! I figure at about 400,000 km, I will be at the Moon's surface. Just another 3 hours! WOOOOOOHOOOOO! maybe this is a glitch? Has anyone else done this?

Hi, me again. I decided to stop when I hit 100,000 km. I hit a max G of 2725.9!!!!!! Holy Cow!! Well my retardo-nauts are still alive. Just wanted to show how much I've done. Thanks for checking this thread out!!! P.S. I still have not slowed down at all.
After thinking about it, I should have shown the vehicle which was launched into space. so here it is. (mostly 3rd party add-ons. )

nice.. you should of waited another 10 minutes or so.. at 120-130k km's the capsule goes into an uncontrolable spin.. quite funny.. as far as the G's go its bogus. they exponetially grow the further you go out.
Deep space is fun. I've gotten to 1.3 billion Gs
1.3 billion G's?! That would be like trying to fly hrough a black hole! That's awsome!
the G-Force indicators break in deep space. No one can survive 2400 g's!!

I'm fairly sure it's not a bug at all. As I said before, with the lack of sun, once you're going fast enough, and you're far enough away from the earth, gravity would not affect you at all. If the KSP simulator is accurate (which it probably isn't at the moment, being so new), then it could take weeks, if not months or years, of running the sim for the speed to decrease due to gravity. Actually, it might never decrease, as the farther away you get from Kearth, the longer gravity takes you slow you down, giving you more time to get farther away, etc. And as there is no air in space (aside from the occasional stray hydrogen atom whose effect is negligible) to cause resistance, unless you hit something you'll never slow down. Unless of course you're talking about the G-force meter breaking, in which case it is a legitimate bug, but OP didn't actually mention that until later on, and was referring to not slowing down, which is normal.
